1. Has work ever been a relevant domain of contact between [q2o1answer] and [q2o2answer]?
Comment: Wolaytta women are employed for domestic work  in private households of townspeople and for work in hotels in Kambaata, Wolaytta men work at construction sites (buildings, roads) in Kambaata and they produce bamboo products (fences, floorings, walls etc.) in Kambaata.

Wording: 2. How long have [q2o1answer] people and [q2o2answer] people worked together for?
Response: The current work-related contact probably started after the mid-nineties.
Comment: The towns started to develop in Kambaata in the mid-nineties, first hotels were built, the economy diversified and this enabled the employment of labourers.

Wording: Coarse time range, numerical
3. What is the time frame when the largest number of people had the most opportunities for interaction in the labour domain?
Comment: The demand of domestic and construction worker is steadily is steadily increasing. Since the population is growing there is also a growing supply of labourers.

Wording: Coarse time range, numerical
4. What other languages, if any, are spoken in the labour domain?
Comment: We believe that we only find people speaking both Kambaata and Wolaytta at the linguistic boundary. So communication between Kambaata and Wolaytta labourers is virtually always in Amharic.

Wording: 5. How commonly are [q2o1answer] people and [q2o2answer] people involved in public modes of production?
6. Is there hierarchy involved in work?
7. Where do [q2o1answer] people and [q2o2answer] people typically work together?
Response: At places which belong to the [q2o1answer]
Comment: Hotels and cafés in Kambaata, building sites in Kambaata, households in Kambaata; but also productions sites outside of Kambaata and Wolaytta (e.g. flower factories in Zway). We have difficulties in deciding between "At places which belong to the Kambaata" and "At places which belong to some other group". However, we can fairly safely say that less Kambaata do labour jobs in Wolaytta than Wolaytta doing these jobs in Kambaata.
Answer1: At places which belong to the [q2o1answer]
Answer2: At places which belong to the [q2o2answer]
Answer3: At places which belong to some other group

Wording: 8. How much influence can the [q2o1answer] exert over the terms of work?
9. Are there any speech styles used during work?
Comment: K. and W. communicate through a third language, Amharic. We have decided to tick "no" because we think Amharic cannot be called a "high variety" of K. or W. In addition, the Amharic that both use can probably called a low variety, namely a regionally tainted southwestern variety of Amharic.

Wording: 10. How often are these speech styles typically used during work, in comparison with unmonitored speech?

12. Do [q2o1answer] people experience work differently depending on social group?
Comment: The question is difficult to answer. The contact between K. and W. does not seem to be much influenced by social group (e.g. gender, caste) in our view. It is rather the type of work you do that determines whether you come into contact with W. or not (e.g. at constructions sites, in hotels). Probably also members of all K. clans/castes could employ W. domestic workers.

33. List any comments or notes that you feel are relevant to this section of the questionnaire.
1. Have [q2o1answer] and [q2o2answer] people occupied the same spaces of knowledge transfer together?
Comment: K. and W. rarely if at all share the same space of knowledge transfer (in our case schools). Administrative zonal boundaries are drawn along ethnic boundaries in Ethiopia. Schools are organised by the zones. In primary level schools, the medium of instruction is the local language (K. and W. in our case), on the secondary level, the medium of instruction is English. There might only be children living at the linguistic/ethnic boundaries between K. and W. that attend the same school (but this is very likely to be exceptional). In the religious context, no spaces are shared either. If K. and W. attend the same space of knowledge transfer (which is definitely exceptional), then the instruction is done in Amharic.
